speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I remain squarely focused on our dual mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since early last year, the FOMC has significantly tightened the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have raised our policy interest rate by 5-1/4 percentage points and have continued to reduce our securities holdings at a brisk pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The stance of policy is restrictive, meaning that tight policy is putting downward pressure on economic activity and inflation, and the full effects of our tightening have yet to be felt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, we decided to leave our policy interest rate unchanged and to continue to reduce our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Given how far we have come, along with the uncertainties and risks we face, the Committee is proceeding carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will make decisions about the extent of additional policy firming and how long policy will remain restrictive based on the totality of the incoming data, the evolving outlook, and the balance of risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will have more to say about monetary policy after briefly reviewing economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent indicators suggest that economic activity has been expanding at a strong pace, and well above earlier expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the third quarter, real GDP is estimated to have risen at an outsized annual rate of 4.9 percent, boosted by a surge in consumer spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: After picking up somewhat over the summer, activity in the housing sector has flattened out and remains well below levels of a year ago, largely reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Higher interest rates also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market remains tight, but supply and demand conditions continue to come into better balance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the past three months, payroll job gains averaged 266 thousand jobs per month, a strong pace that is nevertheless below that seen earlier in the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate remains low, at 3.8 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Strong job creation has been accompanied by an increase in the supply of workers: The labor force participation rate has moved up since late last year, particularly for individuals aged 25 to 54 years, and immigration has rebounded to pre-pandemic levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nominal wage growth has shown some signs of easing, and job vacancies have declined so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although the jobs-to-workers gap has narrowed, labor demand still exceeds the supply of available workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Total PCE prices rose 3.4 percent over the 12 months ending in September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 3.7 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has moderated since the middle of last year, and readings over the summer were quite favorable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But a few months of good data are only the beginning of what it will take to build confidence that inflation is moving down sustainably toward our goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The process of getting inflation sustainably down to 2 percent has a long way to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite elevated inflation, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship as it erodes purchasing power, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks that high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I noted earlier, since early last year, we have raised our policy rate by 5-1/4 percentage points, and we have decreased our securities holdings by more than $1 trillion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our restrictive stance of monetary policy is putting downward pressure on economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee decided at today’s meeting to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 5-1/4 to 5-1/2 percent and to continue the process of significantly reducing our securities holdings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to achieving a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation sustainably down to 2 percent over time, and to keeping policy restrictive until we are confident that inflation is on a path to that objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are attentive to recent data showing the resilience of economic growth and demand for labor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Evidence of growth persistently above potential, or that tightness in the labor market is no longer easing, could put further progress on inflation at risk and could warrant further tightening of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions have tightened significantly in recent months, driven by higher longer-term bond yields, among other factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Because persistent changes in financial conditions can have implications for the path of monetary policy, we monitor financial developments closely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In light of the uncertainties and risks, and how far we have come, the Committee is proceeding carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting, based on the totality of the incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation as well as the balance of risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate to return inflation to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keeping longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below-potential growth and some softening of labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum employment and price stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I look forward to your questions.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let's go to Howard.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Howard Schneider with Reuters.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell, for doing this.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: To what you referenced, the rise in long-term bond yields, to what degree is that the planned action by the Fed at this meeting?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks for your question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I'll talk about bond yields, but I want to take a second and just sort of set the broader context in which we're looking at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, if you look at the situation, let's look at the economy first.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: inflation has been coming down, but it's still running well above our 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market has been rebalancing but it's still very tight by many measures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: GDP growth has been strong, although many forecasters are forecasting and they have been forecasting that it will slow.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As for the Committee, we are committed to achieving a stance of monetary policy that's sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we're not confident yet that we have achieved such a stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that is the broader context into which this strong economy and all the things I said, that's the context in which we're looking at this question of rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, obviously we're monitoring, we're attentive to the increase in longer-term yields and which have contributed to a tightening of broader financial conditions since the summer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, persistent changes in broader financial conditions can have implications for the path of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In this case, the tighter financial conditions we're seeing from higher long-term rates but also from other sources like the stronger dollar and lower equity prices could matter for future rate decisions, as long as two conditions are satisfied.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The first is that the tighter conditions would need to be persistent and that is something that remains to be seen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that's critical, things are fluctuating back and forth, that's not what we're looking for.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With financial conditions, we're looking for persistent changes that are material.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The second thing is that the longer-term rates that have moved up, they can't simply be a reflection of expected policy moves from us that we would then, that if we didn't follow through on them, then the rates would come back down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, and I would say on that, it does not appear that an expectation of higher near-term policy rates is causing the increase in longer-term rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in the meantime though, perhaps the most important thing is that these higher Treasury yields are showing through a higher borrowing cost for households and businesses and those higher costs are going to weigh on economic activity to the extent this tightening persists and the mind's eye goes to the 8 percent, near 8 percent mortgage rate, which could have pretty significant effect on housing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, that's how I would answer your question.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Just as a quick follow on to be clear on this; in your opening statement just now, you seemed to imply that you are not yet confident that financial conditions are restrictive enough to finish the fight.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Is that true?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, that's exactly right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To say it a different way, we haven't made any decisions about future meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have not made a determination and we're not, I will say that we're not confident at this time that we've reached such a stance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We're not confident that we haven't, we're not confident that we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that's, that is the way we're going to be going into these future meetings is to be just determining the extent of any additional further policy tightening that may be appropriate to return inflation to 2 percent over time.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jeana.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hi Chair Powell, thank you so much for taking our questions.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: I wonder if you don't raise interest rates in December, would the presumption be at that point that we should expect that rates are at their peak, or is there a possibility of restarting rate increases next year?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: And are there any costs to taking a more extended pause?

speaker: CHIAIR POWELL
sentence: So, let me start by saying we haven't made a decision about September, you're asking a hypothetical there, but we're going into December meeting, we'll get as you know, two more inflation ratings, two more labor market readings, some data on economic activity and so we'll be taking, and also the broader situation, the broader financial condition situation and broader world situation, we'll be looking at all those things as we make a decision in December.

speaker: CHIAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven't made that decision.

speaker: CHIAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say though that the idea that if you, the idea that would-- difficult to raise again after stopping for a meeting or two, it's just not right.

speaker: CHIAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean the Committee will always do what it thinks is appropriate at the time.

speaker: CHIAIR POWELL
sentence: And again, we haven't made any decisions at all about December.

speaker: CHIAIR POWELL
sentence: We didn't even, we didn't talk about making a decision in December today.

speaker: CHIAIR POWELL
sentence: Really it was a decision for this meeting and understanding broader things.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nick.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos, The Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Chair Powell, did the Fed staff put a recession back into the baseline forecast in the materials for today's meeting?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And how much does this tightening and financial conditions substitute for rate hikes if the tightening is persistent.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: You had said it was worth maybe a quarter point when we had the bank failures in the spring.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: What is it here on something that's presumably more straightforward and more familiar to simulate?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess I don't want to answer your question about the recession, but the answer is no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think I have to answer it, since we did publicly say in the minutes, you'll know anyway in the minutes, the staff did not put a recession back in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean it would be hard to see how you would do that if you look at the activity we've seen recently, which is not really indicative of a recession in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of how to think about translation into rate hikes, I think it's just too early to be doing that, and the main reason is we just don't know how persistent this will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can see how volatile it is, different kinds of news will affect the level of rates and I think any kind of an estimate that was precise would hang out there and have a great chance of looking wrong very quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I think what we can say is that financial conditions have clearly tightened and you can see that in the rates that consumers and households and businesses are paying now, and over time that will have an effect, we just don't know how persistent it's going to be and it's tough to try to translate that in a way that I'd be comfortable communicating to how many rate hikes that is.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: I'd like to follow-up and ask what makes you confident-- what makes you confident in the tighter financial conditions will slow above trend growth when 500 basis points of rate hikes, QT, and a minor banking crisis have not thus far?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, that's you know, the way our policy works is, and sometimes it works with lags of course, which can be long and variable, but ultimately if you raise the interest rates, you do see those affects and you see those effects in the economy now, you see what's happening in the housing market, you're seeing that now, you'll see, if you look at surveys of people, it's not a good time they think to buy durable goods of various kinds because rates are so high now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mentioned again, we're getting reports from housing that the effects of this could be quite significant.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you're right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This has been a resilient economy, and it's I think been surprising in its resilience and there are a number of possible reasons why that may be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our job is to achieve maximum employment and price stability and so we take the economy as it comes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It has been resilient, so we just, we take it as it is.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Colby.

speaker: COLBY SMTH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: COLBY SMTH
sentence: Colby Smith with The Financial Times.

speaker: COLBY SMTH
sentence: In terms of the thresholds that you've laid out of what could warrant further tightening, the additional evidence of persistently above trend growth, or some kind of reversal in the recent easing of labor market tightness, that seems to suggest something more powerful than just one more quarter point rate hike would be necessary.

speaker: COLBY SMTH
sentence: And I'm just curious if that's how the Committee sees it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we've identified those factors, those were not meant to be the only factors or a specific test that we're going to be applying with some metrics behind it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re really going to be looking at the broader picture and what's happening with our progress toward the 2 percent inflation goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Is the labor market continuing to broadly cool off and achieve a better balance, so we'll be looking at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth, we look at growth insofar as it has implications for our two mandate goals, we look at that, and we look at broader financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we'll be looking at all of those things as we reach a judgment, whether we need to further tighten policy and if we do reach that judgment, then we will further tighten policy.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Okay, and just in terms of the tightening of financial conditions, if that is having some kind of offsetting affect in terms of the need to potentially again raise rates, what then is the potential impact on the trajectory of rate cuts?

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Could we see those maybe pulled forward or have to see more than what the September SEP indicated?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it's, the fact is the Committee is not thinking about rate cuts right now at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We're not talking about rate cuts, we're still very focused on the first question, which is; have we achieved a stance of monetary policy that's sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time, sustainably?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That is the question we're focusing on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The next question, as you know, will be for how long will we remain restrictive?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Will policy remain restrictive and what we've said there is that we'll keep policy restrictive until we're confident that inflation is on a sustainable path down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That'll be the next question, but honestly, right now we're really tightly focused on the first question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The question of rate cuts just doesn't come up because I think the first, it's so important to get that first question as close to right as you can.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Steve.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, I guess I have assumed that there was a tightening bias in the Committee, you say in the statement you're looking to assess the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the extent to which you may need to hike additionally.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: You didn't say earlier that you were sufficiently restrictive, there were forecasts for two rate hikes among most members of the Committee, but then you just said that we don't, we haven't made a determination.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Would you say the bias right now is neutral, that there is no disposition to hike again and that the Committee largely has moved off of this forecast for two hikes?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Sorry, one additional— CHAIR POWELL.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: No, I wouldn't say that at all.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I would say, I mean the language looking at it here, in determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate to return inflation to 2 percent over time.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: That's the question we're asking.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: So is it right to think of that as a hiking bias is still in the Committee here?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven't used that term, but it's fair to say that's the question we're asking is, should we hike more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It's not, that is the question, and you're right that in September we wrote down one additional rate hike.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, and we'll write down another forecast, as you know, in December.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Chris.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Thank you, Chris Rugaber, at Associated Press.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Well, since the last meeting, the auto workers' strike has finished, oil prices have leveled off, and yet on the other hand, you have the outbreak of war between Israel and Hamas.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: How do you see all those factors taken together, affecting the economy going forward?

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: How are you thinking about those?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, there are significant issues out there, as you point out, global geopolitical tensions are certainly elevated, and that goes for the war in Ukraine, it goes for the war between Israel and Hamas.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We're monitoring that, our job is to monitor those things for their economic implications.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, the UAW strike, as you point out, appears to be coming to an end.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Oil prices have flattened out, they haven't gone down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess they've gone down a little bit from their earlier peak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Another one is the possibility of government shutdown; we don't know about that one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, there's plenty of risk out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would go back to the bigger picture from our standpoint is, we've got a very strong economy, strong labor market, making progress on labor market, making progress on inflation, and we're very focused on getting confident that we have achieved a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's really our focus.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Great, and just one quick thing.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: You last month had gone to York, Pennsylvania where you talked to a lot of, or, yeah last month, where you talked to a lot of small business owners.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Just curious, what sentiments did you hear from them or what did you pick up on and what would you-- was there anything that surprised you the most in terms of what they talked about?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn't say I was terribly surprised.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I was very impressed by York as a town with a real strategy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say it's very impressive what the people there have put together in the face of some difficult longer run trends about offshoring of manufacturing and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They've done a great job as a city, I think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What you hear, and it's consistent there, which is people are really suffering under high inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You were there, we talked to some people who were feeling that in their businesses and other people who were feeling it in their home lives as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It's painful for people, particularly people who don't have a lot of extra financial resources who are spending most of their income on the essentials of life.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, we know that, that wasn't new.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that did come through very clearly in the conversations we had in York, and I walked away from that even, I mean just thinking that we really, the best thing we can do for the U.S. is to restore price stability, fully restore price stability and not fail in that task and do it as quickly as possible, but also with the least damage we can.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Rachel.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Hi Chair Powell.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Rachel Siegel from the Washington Post.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thanks for taking our questions.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: You've spoken before about the pain that would likely be coming for the economy in order to get inflation down.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: But since the economy has not responded to rate hikes in ways that would normally be expected, have you changed your views on that at all on how necessary or inevitable that kind of pain would be, say for the labor market or overall growth?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well I think everyone has been very gratified to see that we've been able to achieve pretty significant progress on inflation without seeing the kind of increase in unemployment that has been very typical of rate hiking cycles like this one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that's a historically unusual and very welcome result.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the same is true of growth, we've been saying that we need to see below potential growth and growth has been strong but yet we're still seeing this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think I still believe and my colleagues for the most part I think still believe, that is likely to be true.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is still likely to be true, not a certainty but likely that we will need to see some slower growth and some softening in the labor market, in labor market conditions to get to fully restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, but it's only a good thing that we haven't seen it and I think we know why.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since we lifted off, we have understood that there are really two processes at work here, one of which is the unwinding of the distortions to both supply and demand from the Pandemic and the response to the Pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the other is restrictive monetary policy which is moderating demand and giving the supply side time to recover, time and space to recover.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you see those two forces now working together to bring down inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it's that first one can bring down inflation without the need for higher unemployment or slower growth, it's just, it's supply side improvements like shortages and bottlenecks and that kind of thing going away.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It's getting a significant increase in the size of the labor market now, both from labor force participation and from immigration.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's a big supply side gain that is really helping the economy and it's part of why GDP is so high is because we're getting that supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, we welcome that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think those things will run their course and we're probably still going to be left, we think, and I think, we'll still be left with some ground to cover to get back to full price stability and that's where monetary policy and what we do with demand is still going to be important.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Against that backdrop, if you've gotten any clarity on lags.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: If you have an economy that's been so resilient to high rate increases, does that suggest to you that there isn't necessarily this huge wave of tightening that's still coming through the pipeline and that it may have already come into effect?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I continue to think it's very hard to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it's been one year at this meeting, one year ago this was the fourth of our 75 basis points hikes, so that's a full year since then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we are seeing the effects of all the hiking we did last year and this year we're seeing it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It's very hard to know exactly what that might be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you can, for example, an example where you wouldn't have felt this yet is debt that had been termed out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it's going to come due and have to get rolled over next year or the year after.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, and there are little things like that where the effects have just taken time to get into the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don't, I think we have to make monetary policy under great uncertainty about how long the lags are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think trying to make a clear, get a clear answer and say, I'm just going to assume this, is really not a good way to do it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this is one of the reasons why we have slowed the process down this year was to give monetary policy time to get into the economy and it takes time, we know that, and you can't rush it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, doing, slowing down is giving us I think a better sense of how much more we need to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we need to do more.

speaker: MICHELEL SMITH
sentence: Michael.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Michael McKee, from Bloomberg Television and Radio.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: I'm trying to connect the dots here, one quick clarification I wanted to ask about Rachel's question is, you said you need slower growth.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: You had always said before a period of lower than trend growth.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Has that changed?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: And two, it sounds to me like you're basically saying here that the kind of the dot plot's out the window, that every meeting is live with the possibility of a rate increase for right now doesn't matter about the turn of the year.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: And that there's not an objective way to determine whether or not you've got enough tightening in the system.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: It's just going to be a subjective judgment, meeting by meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well so, let's talk about the dot plot first.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, the dot plot is a picture in time of what the people in the Committee thinks is likely to be appropriate monetary policy in light of their own personal economic forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In principle, when things change, it's not, that's not like planned that anybody's agreed to or that we will do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's a forecast that would change, for example, I mean many things could change that would cause people to say, I wouldn't write down that dot six weeks later.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Think of the number of things that could change your mind on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I think the efficacy of the dot plot probably decays over the three-month period between that meeting and the next meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But nonetheless, it's out there, we don't-- we do personally update our forecast, but we don't formally update the dot plot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I think we try to be as transparent as we can about the way we're thinking about these things, we're laying out there our thinking and as we approach the meeting, we'll all be, my colleagues and I will be talking about how we're processing that data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of, so we're not really changing the way, in terms of growth, what I said was below potential, so what you have here recently is growth that is temporarily, potential growth, is elevated for a year or two right now over its trend level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the right way to think about it is, what's potential growth this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People think trend growth over a long period of time is a little bit less than 2 percent or I would say just around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what we've had is with the improvement in the size of the labor force, as I mentioned, through both participation and immigration, and with the better functioning in the labor market with the unwinding of the supply chain and shortages and those kinds of things, you're seeing actually elevated potential growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There's catch up growth that can happen in potential.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that means that if you're growing, you could be growing at 2 percent this year and still be growing below the increase in the potential output of the economy, I hope that's clear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's really what's going on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's why I would say it as below potential.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: But if you could clarify what I asked about the meeting by meeting, are we essentially now supposed to assume that it's a meeting by meeting, live meeting with a chance of a rate increase that will be decided on subjective criteria rather than objective at each meeting?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I don't know that I want to just accept anybody's characterization, but I'll tell you how we're doing this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, we're going meeting by meeting, we're asking ourselves whether we've achieved a stance of policy that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time, that's the question we're asking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We're looking at the full range of economic data, including financial conditions and all of those things that we look at, and then we're-- we've come very far with this rate hiking cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very far.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you saw the spread at the September meeting of, it's a relatively small spread of people think one or two additional hikes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you're close to the end of the cycle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was an impression as of, I believe, as of September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It's not a promise or a plan of the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so we're going into these meetings one by one, we're looking at the data, as I mentioned, we're also, we're being careful, we're proceeding carefully, because we can proceed carefully at this time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Monetary policy is restrictive, we see its affects, particularly in interest sensitive spending, and other channels, so that's how I think about it.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Neil.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: Hi Chair Powell, Neil Irwin with Axios.

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: In light of the run up in long-term yields we've seen the last several weeks, have you given any consideration to the pace of your asset run off program?

speaker: NEIL IRWIN
sentence: And if there were judgment the higher term premium was endangering the dual mandate goals, would that be reason to think about slowing or suspending QT or should we think of it as more technical question around reserves?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, the committee is not considering changing the pace of balance sheet run off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It's not something we're talking about or considering and I know there are many candidate explanations for why rates have been going up and QT is certainly on that list.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It may be playing a relatively small effect, although I would say at $3.3 trillion in reserves, it's not, I think it's hard to make a case that reserves are even close to scarce at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that's not something that we're looking at right now.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Victoria.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi, Victoria Guida with Politico.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: I wanted to ask about the Basel III Endgame capital proposal.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: You've gotten a lot of pushback from people on different aspects of the proposal and you yourself expressed some reservations, and I'm just curious, could you accept finalizing that proposal without significant changes?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, that proposal is out for comment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we expect a lot of comment, we won't get those comments until the end of, well into next year, we've extended the deadline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we'll take them seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We'll read them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I'll say what I do expect is that we will come to a, we're a consensus driven organization, we'll come to a package that it has broad support on the Board.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: So is broad support mean more support than the proposal had?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It means broad support.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jonnelle.

speaker: JONELLE MARTE
sentence: Jonnelle Marte with Bloomberg.

speaker: JONELLE MARTE
sentence: So in addition to persistence, when you look at long-term treasury yields, what else are you watching to evaluate how those tighter financial conditions are hitting the economy and if it will lessen the need for further tightening?

speaker: JONELLE MARTE
sentence: Also, do you think that those higher yields could affect banking stress?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what do we look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We look at a very wide range of financial conditions and in fact, as you'll know, different organizations publish different financial conditions’ indexes which can have seven or eight variables, or they can have a hundred variables, so there's a very rich environment, and we tend to look at a few of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I'm not going to give you the names, but they're, a few of the common ones that people look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so they're looking at things like the level of the dollar, level of equity prices, the level of rates, the credit spreads, sometimes they're pulling in credit availability, and things like that, so it isn't any one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would never look at for example, long-term treasury rates in isolation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nor would we ignore them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we would look at them as part of a broader picture and they do play a role of course, in many of the major standard financial condition indexes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Your second question was?

speaker: JONELLE MARTE
sentence: On the banking stress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Banking stress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, it's something we're watching, as you know, we did have, there were issues with the interest rate risk and also funding, uninsured deposits in the March, the things we went through in March and thereafter and so we've been working a lot with financial institutions to make sure that they have good funding plans and good, and that they have a plan for how to deal with the kind of portfolio unrealized losses that they have, and we do think the banking system is quite resilient, we had a handful of bank failures but so that's what we're out there doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don't have any reason to think that these rate hikes are materially changing that picture.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Which is one of a strong banking system and one where there's a strong focus by banks and by supervisors on liquidity, on funding and those sorts of things.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Scott.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Thanks Mr. Chairman.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Scott Horsley from NPR.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Last week you and your colleagues put forward a proposal to lower the cap on debit card swipe fees for comment, could you just talk a little bit about the considerations there, what it would mean for merchants, for banks, for consumers, and also just what you all are seeing in terms of the use of both debit and credit cards in the payment system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you're right, we put a proposal out for comment is what we did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this is a job that Congress assigned us as you, of course know, in Dodd-Frank, and all we can really do is faithfully implement the statute, that's all we're trying to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What else can we really do?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It's a 90-day comment period and we typically don't comment on these things once they're out for comment, and we do hope that stakeholders and we know that they will use this opportunity to express their views.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They haven't been shy about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that's critical and that's what I can say about that now.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Edward.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Thank you, thanks Chair.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Edward Lawrence with FOX Business.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So for the last three months, the year over year PCE inflation was at 3.4 percent, core well over 3 percent.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: You've said in the past, 2 percent remains the Federal Reserve target, but with no rate increase today, how long would you be okay then with a 3 percent or 3 percent plus overall inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The progress is probably going to come in lumps and be bumpy, but we're making progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the core PCE came down by almost 60 basis points in the third quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, the best thing I could point you to would be the September SEP where the expectation was that inflation by the end of next year, on a 12-month trailing basis, would be well into the twos.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the year after that, further into the twos.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that's, if you look historically, that's sort of consistent with the way inflation comes down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It does take some time and as you get, as you get further and further from those highs, it may actually take longer time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the good news is, we're making progress and monetary policy is restrictive and we feel like we're on a path to make more progress and it's essential that we do.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: But you've said in the past that doing too little on interest rates could take years to fix, but the cost of doing too much could be easily fixed.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: How robust was the debate about this pause on the doing too little side?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's always the question we're asking ourselves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we know that if we fail to restore price stability, the risk is that expectations of higher inflation get entrenched in the economy and we know that that's really bad for people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation will be both higher and more volatile, that's a prescription for misery, and so we're really committed to not letting that happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For the first year or so of our tightening cycle, the risk was all on the side of not doing enough.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We're, we've come far enough that the risks have gotten more two-sided.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can't identify that with a lot of precision but it does feel like the risks are more two-sided now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, but we're committed to getting inflation back down to our target over time and we will.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Simon.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVICH
sentence: Hi, Simon Rabinovitch with The Economist.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVICH
sentence: Quick follow-up to the question about banking stresses.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVICH
sentence: You talked about how the banking system is resilient, of course part of resilience the past year stems from the bank term funding program that you launched in March.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVICH
sentence: Given that bond prices have not recovered, that unrealized losses are probably mounting, how likely is it that you might have to extend that program in March next year?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good question, we haven't really, we haven't really been thinking about that yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, it's November 1, and that's a decision we'll be making in the first quarter of next year.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVICH
sentence: Okay, sorry, quick second question about inflation expectations, the U Michigan Sentiment Survey showed a big jump in one year ahead inflation expectations last month from 3.2 to 4.2.

speaker: SIMON RABINOVICH
sentence: Last year you said that particular survey was a really decisive factor in one of your rate hike decisions, if it stays elevated next time around, how big of an input will that be into your December thinking?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah, we look at a range of things, I think the UM thing got blown out of proportion a little bit, it was actually a preliminary estimate that got revised away, and I said it was preliminary in it, but that didn't get picked up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, we look at many, many things, so really, look across the broad array of surveys and also market based estimates, and we do that really carefully at every meeting and between meetings, and there's, it's just clear that inflation expectations are in a good place, the public does believe that inflation will get back down to 2 percent over time, and it will, they're right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, and there's no real crack in that armor, you can always find one reading that is a little bit out of whack but honestly, the bulk of them are just very clear that the public believes that inflation will come down and that's of course, we believe that's critical in winning the battle.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Megan.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: Hi Chair Powell, Megan Cassella with Barron's.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: Thanks for taking our questions.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: I wanted to see if you could talk about the neutral rate.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: You mentioned today that you're still debating whether rates are sufficiently restrictive and you've recently said that evidence is suggesting policy is not too tight right now.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: So I was curious if you could elaborate on that at all and whether that means the neutral rate in your view has risen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah, so first thing to say is that it's very important, it's a very important variable in the way we think about monetary policy, but you can't identify it with any precision in real-time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you have to just take that, you have to take your estimate of it with a grain of salt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we know now is within a range of estimates of the neutral rate policy, is restrictive, and it's therefore putting downward pressure on economic activity, hiring, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do talk about this, there's not any debate or attempt to sort of agree as a group on what, whether r star has moved or not, some people think it has, some people haven't said, that don't think it has.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Ultimately it's unknowable, and so really again, what we're focused on is looking at the data and giving ourselves a little more time now to look carefully at the data by being careful in our moves, does it feel like monetary policy is restrictive enough to bring inflation down to 2 percent over time?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's the question we're asking ourselves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think years from now economists will be revising their estimates of r star as it existed on November 1, 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can't, we can't really wait for that in making policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have to look, we have to have those models and look at them and think about them and ultimately we've got to look at the effects that policy is having, accounting for the lags, which makes is difficult.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: If I could follow-up on a wages point.

speaker: MEGAN CASSELLA
sentence: Earlier you talked about the inflation outlook, but I'm curious if you have any concerns whether wage inflation at its current level could be, could risk pushing up overall inflation or re-accelerate inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at the broad range of wages, they have, wage increases have really come down significantly over the course of the last 18 months to a level where they're substantially closer to that level that would be consistent with 2 percent inflation over time, making standard assumptions about productivity over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it's much closer than it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that's true of the ECI, which is the one that we got this week, it's true of average hourly earnings and compensation per hour too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, and all of them are kind of saying that, which is great.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you have to look at a group of them because any one of them can be idiosyncratic from, in any given reading.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that's what you see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so what you saw with the ECI reading was if you look back a couple, it comes out four times a year, if you look back a couple of quarters, you'll see it was much higher and it came down substantially in June, and then September reading was more or less at the same level as the June reading, so in a way, it's just validating that decline, and it was very close to our expectations internally too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I think we feel good about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Also I would say it isn't, in my thinking, it's not the case that wages have been the principle driver of inflation so far, although I think it's all, I do think it's fair to say that as we go forward, as monetary policy becomes more important relative to the supply side issues I’ve talked about in the unwinding of the pandemic effects, it may be that the labor market becomes more important over time too.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nancy.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Hi, Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Chair Powell, are you now as concerned about overshooting and raising interest rates too much as you are about getting inflation down to the 2 percent target?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So as I mentioned, I think for much of the last year and a half, the concern was not doing too-- not doing enough, it was not getting rates high enough in time to avoid having inflation expectations, higher inflation expectations become entrenched, so that was the concern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we've reached now more than 18 months into this, you can see by the fact that we have slowed down, although we're still trying to gain confidence in what the appropriate stance is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you can see that, we think, and I think, that the risks are getting more balanced.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I'll just say that, they're getting more balanced.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The risk of doing too much versus the risk of doing too little are getting closer to balance, because policy is I think clearly restrictive at 5-1/4 to 5-1/2 percent, that range, if you take off a mainstream estimate of the expected inflation, take one year inflation, you're going to see that you're going to see a real policy rate that is well above mainstream estimates of a neutral policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now that's arithmetic, it doesn't really, the proof is really in how the economy reacts, but I would say that we're in a place where those risks are getting closer to being in balance.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Okay, and you said the proof is how the economy reacts.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: What are you looking at to be sure you're not overshooting?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think what we're looking at is are we still, is inflation still broadly cooling?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Do we, is it sort of validating the path we saw over the summer, where inflation was clearly cooling and coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now we've seen periods like that before, and they've just, there hasn’t been follow through, the data have bounced back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what are we seeing?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Are we seeing, is inflation still coming down?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that's the first thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The second thing is in the labor market, what we've seen is a very positive rebalancing of supply and demand, partly through just much more supply coming online and with labor demand still clearly remaining very strong, when you have the kind of job growth we've had over the last quarter, it's still very strong demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So and you see wage increases coming down as we discussed, but coming down in a kind of gradual way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that's what we, that's what we want to see, that whole set of processes continue.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Bryan.

speaker: BRYAN MENA
sentence: Bryan Mena, CNN.

speaker: BRYAN MENA
sentence: Do you think that there has been any structural change in either consumption or in the job market that's pushing at consumption?

speaker: BRYAN MENA
sentence: You obviously saw the third quarter GDP figures, which were strong and some economists have expect everyone’s spending to have fizzled out by now, so I'm kind of wondering if there's been any structural change in consumption.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn't say there's been a structural change in consumption, I would say it's certainly been strong, and so a couple of things, we may have underestimated the balance sheet strength of households and small businesses, and that may be part of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There may be, we've been like everyone else, trying to estimate the number of the amount of savings that households have from the pandemic when they couldn't spend on services really at all, or in-person services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there can still be more of that than we think, although at a certain point we have to, we're going to be getting back to pre-pandemic levels of savings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We may not be there yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So things are, for clearly people are still spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The dynamic has been really strong job creation with now wages that are higher than inflation, in the aggregate anyway, and that raises real disposable income, and that raises spending, which continues to drive more hiring, and so you've had a really, that whole dynamic has been, and also at the same time, the pandemic effects are wearing off so that goods availability, automobile availability is better, or was better, I think it still is, and from a business standpoint, there are more people to hire.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it is more labor supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the whole thing has led to more growth, more spending, and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And It's been good, and the thing is, we've been achieving progress on inflation in the middle of this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, it's been a dynamic, the question is how long can that continue?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I just think this, the existence of this second set of factors at this time, which is the unwinding of the pandemic effects, that's what makes this cycle unique I think, and we're still learning, that took longer for that process to begin than we thought, and we're still learning about how it plays out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That's all we can do.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Daniel for the last question.

speaker: DANIEL AVIS
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell.

speaker: DANIEL AVIS
sentence: I'm Daniel Avis from Agence France-Presse.

speaker: DANIEL AVIS
sentence: Just a quick question following up on an earlier one with regards to the Israel-Hamas conflict.

speaker: DANIEL AVIS
sentence: The Fed's Financial Stability Report said the Israel-Hamas conflict and the conflict in Ukraine pose important risks to global economic activity, including the possibility of sustained disruptions to regional trade and food, energy and other commodities.

speaker: DANIEL AVIS
sentence: You've had organizations at the World Bank warning of a possibly surge in oil prices if the war spreads to other countries in the region.

speaker: DANIEL AVIS
sentence: I'm just wondering how the Fed is monitoring these developments in the Middle East, you mentioned they are, and just what the potential economic impact could be if the conflict does spread to other countries in the region.

speaker: DANIEL AVIS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn't want to speculate too much, but I'll just say so, really the question there is does the war spread more widely and does it start to do things like affect oil prices in particular, since this is the Middle East we're talking about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The price of oil has really not reacted very much so far to this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the Fed, as the Federal Open Market Committee, our job is really to talk about, to understand the economy and economic effects and it isn't clear at this point that the conflict in the Middle East is going to, is on track to have significant economic effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That doesn't mean it isn't incredibly important, and something for people to take really important notice of, but it may or may not turn out to be something that matters for the Federal Open Market Committee as an economic body.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, so what the Financial Stability Report does is it calls out risks and that's what it's doing is calling out a risk of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the war in Ukraine, the same.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The war in Ukraine did have immediately very significant macroeconomic implications because of the connection to commodities.
